text: paints companies have been on the hunt
for the perfect antifouling coating for
ocean vessels ever since the
antimicrobial agent tributyl tin was
banned in 2008 because of its toxicity
to marine life the ideal product needs
to prevent bacterial build-up be safe
for the environment and improve the
vessels performance not only do we want
to stop fouling from settling on the
bottom of it of the vessel but we also
want to improve the hydrodynamics of the
vessel through the water companies such
as Dutch paints and chemicals firm acts
Annabelle are seeking to develop low
friction paints which enable vessels to
cut through the water with less drag
saving fuel while also preventing
microbes from attaching to the coating
surface if you have a vessel which has
got fouling on the outside of it then it
slows the vessel down and that means
that either you have to burn more fossil
fuel in order for the vessel to move
faster or you the vessels slower through
the water so for our customers it's key
to keep fouling off the bottom of their
vessels act so no bells into sleek
fluoropolymer coatings for ships can
reduce greenhouse gas emissions from
fuel by up to nine percent compared with
standard antifouling paint that
technology axes of smooth surface which
reduces the drag of the vessel through
the water and provides good fouling
control for the for the customer the
dutch firm continues to evaluate
different paint formulations that can
further reduce the friction of inter
sleek and it may be well on its way to
finding that perfect antifouling paint
for chemical and engineering use this is
Alex Scott
